body:
And here are version and environment details:

~~~sh
$ source .venv/bin/activate
$ pip list
Package        Version
-------------- -------
attrs          18.1.0
more-itertools 4.1.0
pip            10.0.1
pkg-resources  0.0.0
pluggy         0.6.0
py             1.5.3
pytest         3.5.1
setuptools     32.3.1
six            1.11.0
wheel          0.31.0
~~~

~~~sh
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 17.10
Release:        17.10
Codename:       artful
~~~

~~~sh
$ py.test --version
This is pytest version 3.5.1, imported from /home/vagrant/foobar/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest.py
~~~

the issue comes from passing the mock object to doctest inadvertently
i believe this is an issue with the stdlib being broken, im not sure if pytest can do something about it

hmm, I'd also found another workaround, through `pytest-mock` plugin, using `mocker` fixture and avoiding import of `unittest.mock`:

~~~python
# tests/test_with_mock_package.py

def test_simple(mocker):
    mock_obj = mocker.Mock()
~~~

* note that in this case there is no `from unittest.mock import Mock, call`

Going that route doesn't break `py.test`...

I guess this one can be invalidated then? As for the stdlib, I might find time to figure out if this was reported, and report it there...
as long as there is no superseeding upstream issue i'd like to leave this one open

OK, think I've found it: https://bugs.python.org/issue25532. Seems like there is a kind of fix for it in Python 3.7. I'd tested it with 3.7b4 and it is better - exception instead of RAM exhaustion

~~~log
============================================================== ERRORS ===============================================================
_________________________________________ ERROR collecting tests/test_with_mock_package.py __________________________________________
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/doctest.py:932: in find
    self._find(tests, obj, name, module, source_lines, globs, {})
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/doctest.py:991: in _find
    if ((inspect.isroutine(inspect.unwrap(val))
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/inspect.py:515: in unwrap
    raise ValueError('wrapper loop when unwrapping {!r}'.format(f))
E   ValueError: wrapper loop when unwrapping call
====================================================== short test summary info ======================================================
ERROR tests/test_with_mock_package.py
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Interrupted: 1 errors during collection !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
====================================================== 1 error in 0.18 seconds ======================================================
~~~
indeed, seems python is broken enough there to fall to warrant a workaround
Can we close this or @RonnyPfannschmidt are you we should do something in pytest as a workaround?
@nicoddemus we should investigate the cost of a workaround at least

Previously reported as #1217.

It's easy enough to [check if an object is a mock](https://github.com/HypothesisWorks/hypothesis/blob/0b9d1a5d713e8c1bd29343ebbd079ad57e31ecb9/hypothesis-python/src/hypothesis/internal/reflection.py#L49-L60), but turning that into a workaround in pytest (instead of Python) might be difficult.

@Zac-HD thanks for that snippet, interesting approach to the problem.

I propose to close this, because (IIUC) we can't fix this because the parsing is done by the builtin `doctest` module.

issue.title: pytest --doctest-modules freezes computer

labels.name: type: question
labels.description: general question, might be closed after 2 weeks of inactivity

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Hello, when I execute `pytest --doctest-modules` in my project [PluginsManager](https://github.com/PedalPi/PluginsManager) the computer freezes and I need reboot!

You can see here the problem: https://travis-ci.org/PedalPi/PluginsManager/jobs/289297278#L1156-L1166

## How to

I tried on my computer on the `virtualenv` and in the `docker` and in both the computer freezes. Also, [`travis` freezes too](https://travis-ci.org/PedalPi/PluginsManager/jobs/289297278#L1156-L1166).

```
# In docker
#sudo docker run -it python:3.6 bash
#cd tmp/
git clone https://github.com/PedalPi/PluginsManager
cd PluginsManager/
python setup.py develop
git checkout 72b2e6e507cfe23c2cf011f6ded08f2f9ffd2b65
pip install pytest
pytest --doctest-modules # WILL FREEZE PC
```

## `pip list` of the virtual environment you are using

```
cffi (1.11.2)
JACK-Client (0.4.2)
PedalPi-PluginsManager (0.5.1, /tmp/PluginsManager)
pip (9.0.1)
py (1.4.34)
PyAudio (0.2.11)
pycparser (2.18)
pytest (3.2.3)
setuptools (36.6.0)
wheel (0.30.0)
```

body: there is a semi-simple workaround requiring a wrapper - i fixed it on python2, but need some more to fix it on modern python3 (which detects the actual wrapper loop) - the fix itself already makes the situation better on python2, but still fails users on python3 in a way

issue.title: Feature/python sampling

repository.name: keanu
repository.description: A probabilistic approach from an Improbabilistic company

issue.body:
Implemented:
- Pythonic api for `sample`
- Java wrapper now only permits snake case, and calls Java API if there is no python implementation
- 3 MCMC sampling algorithms
- Java list or set of vertices are now all converted to python list or set
- Some extensions to vertex wrapper (e.g. vertex ids (as string))
- Some extensions to bayesian network wrapper to return python lists of vertices
- KeanuRandom wrapper

Excluded:
- Model composition APIs (e.g. `getTopLevelLatentVertices`, vertex labels)

body:
I've encountered this issue on python 3.6.7 and pytest 4.1.0... is there a workaround such as disabling doctests on a single file?

To reproduce, create a file "example.py" that contains:
```
from unittest.mock import Mock, call
```
Then run pytest --doctest-modules example.py. Output:

```
============================================================================ test session starts ============================================================================
platform linux -- Python 3.6.7, pytest-4.1.0, py-1.7.0, pluggy-0.8.1 -- /root/dev/shared/repos/AperioCommon/.tox/py36/bin/python
cachedir: .pytest_cache
rootdir: /root/dev/shared/repos/AperioCommon, inifile: pytest.ini
plugins: cov-2.6.1, backports.unittest-mock-1.4
collected 0 items / 1 errors

================================================================================== ERRORS ===================================================================================
________________________________________________________________________ ERROR collecting example.py ________________________________________________________________________
/root/.pyenv/versions/3.6.7/lib/python3.6/doctest.py:933: in find
    self._find(tests, obj, name, module, source_lines, globs, {})
/root/.pyenv/versions/3.6.7/lib/python3.6/doctest.py:992: in _find
    if ((inspect.isroutine(inspect.unwrap(val))
/root/.pyenv/versions/3.6.7/lib/python3.6/inspect.py:516: in unwrap
    raise ValueError('wrapper loop when unwrapping {!r}'.format(f))
E   ValueError: wrapper loop when unwrapping call
============================================================================= warnings summary ==============================================================================
.tox/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/_pytest/config/__init__.py:730
  /root/dev/shared/repos/AperioCommon/.tox/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/_pytest/config/__init__.py:730: PytestWarning: Module already imported so cannot be rewritten: backports
    self._mark_plugins_for_rewrite(hook)

-- Docs: https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/warnings.html
==================================================================== 1 warnings, 1 error in 1.55 seconds ====================================================================
```

Also, FYI I do already use a python wrapper to run pytest. It eventually calls:
```
import pytest
return pytest.main(args)
```
One workaround I can think of is to inspect the errors and ignore these specific "wrapper loop" errors. How do we get access to the error list using pytest module?

Another work around, as I mentioned in my first comment, is to disable running doctests for the suspect files. Do we have ability to run doctests only in a specific directory, to detect doctests only with a specific file name, or to skip doctests for certain files?

Thanks!
im just picking up my branch to set up the finder object correctly
